column1: Ewing Township is a township in Mercer County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States. The township is within the New York metropolitan area as defined by the United States Census Bureau. It also directly borders the Philadelphia metropolitan area and is part of the Federal Communications Commission's Philadelphia Designated Market Area. As of the 2010 United States Census

column1: The earliest inhabitants of present-day Ewing Township in the historic era were Lenni Lenape Native Americans
column2: who lived along the banks of the Delaware River. Their pre-colonial subsistence activities in the area included hunting
column3: fishing
column7: began to colonize the area in 1699. One of the earliest European settlers was William Green
column8: and his 1717 farmhouse still stands on the campus of The College of New Jersey.The area that is now Ewing Township was part of Hopewell Township in what was a very large Burlington County at the beginning of the 18th century. In 1714 Hopewell was removed from Burlington County and added to Hunterdon County. By 1719
column9: the area which was to become Ewing Township had been removed from Hopewell Township and added to the newly created Trenton Township. Portions of Trenton Township were incorporated as Ewing Township by an act of the New Jersey Legislature on February 22
column11: posthumously honoring Charles Ewing for his work as Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court. The township became part of the newly created Mercer County on February 22
column13: Ewing Township received additional territory taken from Lawrence Township and the city of Trenton in 1858. In 1894 the city of Trenton took back some of that territory
column14: annexing more in 1900.When Ewing Township was incorporated in the 19th century
column15: it was primarily farmland with a handful of scattered hamlets
column18: Birmingham (now known as West Trenton) and Greensburg (now known as Wilburtha). Since the beginning of the 20th century
column19: the township has developed as a suburb of Trenton. The sections near the city border are distinctly urban
column20: but most of the township is suburban residential development. The main commercial district extends along North Olden Avenue Extension (County Route 622)
column21: originally constructed to connect north Trenton residences with the now-closed General Motors Inland Fisher Guide Plant. Ewing Township today is the location of The College of New Jersey
column22: the Community Blood Council of New Jersey
column24: the Jones Farm State Correction Institute
column26: the New Jersey Department of Transportation headquarters
column27: the Katzenbach School for the Deaf and Trenton-Mercer Airport.

column1: From 1953 until 1997 Ewing was the home of Naval Air Warfare Center Trenton
column2: encompassing 528 acres (214 ha) on Parkway Avenue. It was used by the United States Navy as a jet engine test facility until its closure based on the recommendations of the 1993 Base Closure and Realignment Commission. Nearly 700 civilian positions were eliminated
column3: most of which were relocated to other facilities in Maryland and Tennessee. The base's Marine operations were transferred to Fort Dix
column4: which has since become Joint Base McGuire-Dix-Lakehurst. A charity to end homelessness acquired the base at no cost in October 2013 in a process involving the United States Department of Defense
column5: the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development
column6: Mercer County and Ewing Township.The first location of an industrial robot used to replace human workers was at Ewing's Inland Fisher Guide Plant in 1961
column7: a facility that operated in the township for 1938 to 1998
column8: after which the plant was demolished and targeted for redevelopment.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the township had a total area of 15.56 square miles (40.29 km2)
column3: including 15.21 square miles (39.38 km2) of land and 0.35 square miles (0.90 km2) of water (2.24%).

column1: The highest elevation in Ewing Township is 225 feet (69 m) AMSL just east of Interstate 95 and just west of Trenton-Mercer Airport
column2: while the lowest point is just below 20 feet (6.1 m) AMSL along the Delaware River near the border with Trenton.The largest body of water completely within the township is Lake Sylva
column3: a man-made lake that was created in the 1920s when an earthen dam was constructed across the Shabakunk Creek. The 11-acre (4.5 ha) lake is located on the campus of The College of New Jersey. Watercourses in Ewing include the Delaware River along its western boundary and the Shabakunk Creek in the eastern and central portions of the township.

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Ewing Township
column3: New Jersey has a hot-summer
column5: humid continental climate (Dfa). Dfa climates are characterized by at least one month having an average mean temperature ≤ 32.0 °F (≤ 0.0 °C)
column6: at least four months with an average mean temperature ≥ 50.0 °F (≥ 10.0 °C)
column7: at least one month with an average mean temperature ≥ 71.6 °F (≥ 22.0 °C)
column8: and no significant precipitation difference between seasons. During the summer months
column9: episodes of extreme heat and humidity can occur with heat index values ≥ 100 °F (≥ 38 °C). On average
column10: the wettest month of the year is July which corresponds with the annual peak in thunderstorm activity. During the winter months
column11: episodes of extreme cold and wind can occur with wind chill values < 0 °F (< -18 °C). The plant hardiness zone at the Ewing Township Municipal Court is 7a with an average annual extreme minimum air temperature of 0.2 °F (-17.7 °C). The average seasonal (November–April) snowfall total is 24 to 30 inches (610 to 760 mm) and the average snowiest month is February which corresponds with the annual peak in nor'easter activity.

column1: Ewing Township is governed under the Faulkner Act
column2: formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law
column3: within the Mayor-Council plan 2 form of New Jersey municipal government
column6: based on the recommendations of a Charter Study Commission. The township is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide governed under this form. The township's governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the five-member Township Council
column7: all of whom are elected by the voters at-large to four-year terms of office on a staggered basis. with either three seats up for election or two seats and the mayoral seat up together in even-numbered years as part of the November general election.As of 2020
column8: the Mayor of Ewing Township is Democrat Bert H. Steinmann
column9: whose term of office ends December 31

column2: the district
column3: comprised of five schools

column2: 118; 9-12).A court case filed in 1946 challenged a policy of the Ewing Public Schools under which the district provided bus transportation to students living in the districts who attended private parochial schools. In Everson v. Board of Education
column3: the Supreme Court of the United States ruled for the first time that state and local government were subject to the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution
column4: but that it had not been violated in this instance.The Ewing Public Education Foundation
column7: not-for-profit citizen's organization whose mission is to mobilize community support
column9: commitment and resources to help improve the quality of education in Ewing Township. EPEF provides grants to Ewing Township Schools for innovative educational programs through fund-raising activities
column10: and corporate and institutional sponsorship. The Foundation also seeks to match corporate and organizational donors with teachers to fund additional projects of mutual interest. These programs enhance the educational experience without the use of additional taxpayer dollars.Eighth grade students from all of Mercer County are eligible to apply to attend the high school programs offered by the Mercer County Technical Schools
column11: a county-wide vocational school district that offers full-time career and technical education at its Health Sciences Academy
column12: STEM Academy and Academy of Culinary Arts
column13: with no tuition charged to students for attendance. The Thomas J. Rubino Academy (formerly Mercer County Alternative High School) is one of Mercer County's only alternative schools
column14: offering an alternative educational program for students who have struggled in the traditional school environment
column16: mentoring and counseling.The Marie H. Katzenbach campus of the New Jersey School for the Deaf serves 175 hearing-impaired students on a campus covering 148 acres (60 ha) that was opened in West Trenton in 1926. The school was established in Ewing through the efforts of Marie Hilson Katzenbach and was renamed in her honor in 1965.Incarnation-St. James Catholic School (formerly Incarnation School)
column18: is a Pre-K to 8th grade parish school administered by The Sisters
column19: Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary and overseen by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Trenton. The school added a parish center in 2003
column25: and a kitchenette to be used to the benefit of its students
column28: the Incarnation School and parish combined with the St. James School and parish.The Villa Victoria Academy is a private Catholic school in Ewing Township
column29: christened as a private academy in 1933
column30: and operated by the Religious Teachers Filippini. This single-gender school offers an education to young women from sixth to twelfth grade.The College of New Jersey (formerly Trenton State College) is located on a campus covering 289 acres (117 ha) within the township.

column1: Ewing Township is traversed by multiple main roadways
column2: as well as by a passenger rail line and is the location of an airport.
the township had a total of 149.74 miles (240.98 km) of roadways
column3: of which 108.73 miles (174.98 km) were maintained by the municipality
column5: 12.65 miles (20.36 km) by the New Jersey Department of Transportation
column6: which also has its headquarters in Ewing
column7: and 0.20 miles (0.32 km) by the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission.Interstate 295 (the Scudder Falls Freeway and Bridge) crosses the northwestern section of the township. It is a 55 to 65 miles per hour (89 to 105 km/h)
column8: 4-6 lane divided freeway facility. Originally part of Interstate 95
column9: it was constructed as a four-lane facility in the 1960s
column10: and widened to six lanes in the 1990s
column11: with the exception of the Scudder Falls Bridge over the Delaware River. It connects south with Philadelphia
column12: Pennsylvania and connects north to U.S. 1
column13: where Interstate 295 curves south. From there
column14: travelers use U.S. 1 or Interstate 195 and the New Jersey Turnpike to reach the next major destination northwards
column15: New York City. The Ewing portion of Interstate 95 was redesignated as Interstate 295 in March 2018 ahead of a direct interchange between Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Turnpike being completed
column16: re-routing Interstate 95 onto the New Jersey Turnpike at Exit 6 (in Mansfield Township).

column1: U.S. Route 206 (Princeton Avenue) skirts the southeastern section of the township. It is a 25 miles per hour (40 km/h)
column2: undivided four-lane roadway. Although part of US 206
column3: it is actually maintained by the Mercer County Department of Transportation as part of County Route 583
column4: which runs as a concurrency with US 206. US 206 also connects south to Trenton
column5: as well as north to Princeton and Somerville.

column1: Route 29 (Daniel Bray Highway and River Road) extends north–south along the western edge of the township
column2: along the Delaware River. The southern section
column3: Daniel Bray Highway
column5: divided four-lane facility with at-grade intersections and traffic lights
column6: and was constructed in the 1950s. The northern section
column9: undivided two-lane facility whose construction as a state highway dates from the 1930s. NJ 29 connects southwards to Trenton
column10: and northwards to Lambertville and Frenchtown. The entire section of Route 29 in Ewing is designated the Delaware River Scenic Byway
column11: a National Scenic Byway. Route 175 serves as a frontage road along the divided portion of Route 29.

column1: Route 31 (Pennington Road) extends north–south towards the eastern side of the township. It is a 35-45 mph (60–70 km/h)
column2: undivided four-lane facility whose construction as a state highway also dates to the 1930s. It once also carried a trolley line
column3: but it has long since been removed. It was once proposed to be bypassed by a freeway
column4: but this plan has since been cancelled. NJ 31 also connects south to Trenton

column1: The West Trenton Station is at the terminus of SEPTA's West Trenton Line. This commuter rail facility mainly serves commuter traffic to and from Philadelphia. NJ Transit has proposed a new West Trenton Line of its own
column2: that would stretch for 27 miles (43 km) from the West Trenton Station to a connection with the Raritan Valley Line at Bridgewater Township
column3: and from there to Newark Penn Station in Newark.Ewing Township is the site of the Trenton-Mercer Airport (TTN)
column4: which first opened in 1929 and is one of three commercial airports in the state. The airport has 100
column6: and is served by Frontier Airlines
column7: which offers nonstop service to and from 10 different locations nationwide.Ewing Township is also traversed by the Delaware and Raritan Canal near the Delaware River. Originally important to commerce and trade
column8: the advent of railroads caused the canal's commercial demise. The strip of land along the canal is currently part of the Delaware and Raritan Canal State Park.

The William Greene Farmhouse was the home of Judge William Greene
column2: who was born in the 1600s in England and died in 1722 in Hunterdon County
column3: New Jersey. The William Green House is on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places and the New Jersey Register of Historic Places.

column1: Delaware and Raritan Canal - Runs along the eastern bank of the Delaware River in western Ewing Township.
Washington Victory Trail - Documents the trail taken by George Washington's army during the American Revolution on December 26
column2: 1776.  This led to a successful surprise attack on the Hessian troops occupying Trenton
column3: New Jersey.  Victory trail begins in nearby Washington Crossing State Park
column4: enters Ewing Township at Jacobs Creek Road (where George Washington's and his horse almost fell into the creek) and continues along Bear Tavern Road.  General Sullivan's route follows Grand Avenue and Sullivan Way to Trenton.  General Greene's route follows Parkway Avenue to Trenton.

column1: Ewing Presbyterian Church is an historic building dated 1867 and set within the American Revolution era Ewing Church Cemetery.  It is the fourth church to be built in the cemetery grounds.  The current church building has been under threat of demolition after several engineering studies found the roof trusses are buckling and beyond the point of cost effective repair.  Numerous preservation groups say that the structural problems are much easier to resolve than the studies claim.  Various organizations have endeavored to raise funds to secure the stability of the original church structure.
Our Lady of Good Counsel Church
column2: located on W. Upper Ferry Road
column3: is a Roman Catholic church built in the early 1960s to meet the growing needs of the rapidly expanding township.  Its architecture is similar to Saint Paul's Church in Princeton.  The Church is a major worship center for the Catholic community in what is called the West Trenton section of the township.
